# Best Bluetooth speakers 2020: Top portable speakers to buy today

Bluetooth speakers come in all different shapes and sizes - from larger
options that have the power to fill your whole living room, to smaller
portables that are great for taking to picnics or moving from room-to-room.

Finding the right speaker for you and your needs is no easy task, so we've
rounded up our pick of the best portable speakers currently available to buy.
You'll find a mix of styles, power, sizes and budgets.

There can be some crossover with [Wi-Fi or wireless
speakers](/speakers/buyers-guides/146218-best-wireless-speakers), but in this
roundup we've concentrated on units that are predominantly designed to stand
alone and use Bluetooth for a direct connection with your phone or another
device.

## Our pick of the best Bluetooth speakers to buy today

Pocket-lint

## Bang & Olufsen Beosound A1 2nd Gen

squirrel_widget_239630

If you're looking for a portable Bluetooth speaker - and can forgive the lack
of Wi-Fi, AirPlay, and a 3.5mm port - then the Bang & Olufsen Beosound A1 2nd
Gen is unrivalled. With added Alexa voice control and waterproofing it's
clearly superior to the already awesome original.

For many the elephant in the room will be the Beosound A1 2nd Gen's asking
price. No, this isn't a low-cost speaker. But, yes, it most definitely is a
high-quality one that delivers huge sound from a beautifully made package.

It might be small, but the Beosound A1 2nd Gen packs a big punch that makes it
worth every penny. We can name no better portable at this scale.

  * [Read our Beosound A1 2nd Gen review](https://www.pocket-lint.com/speakers/reviews/bang-and-olufsen/152302-beosound-a1-2nd-gen-review-bang-olufsen-portable-bluetooth)
  * [Best Bang & Olufsen speaker: Which B&O is right for you?](https://www.pocket-lint.com/speakers/buyers-guides/140759-best-bang-and-olufsen-speakers)

Pocket-lint

## Ultimate Ears Megaboom 3

squirrel_widget_145462

The UE Megaboom is a standout product; one only really limited by the high
price point. But even the high price can't muddy the raft of good points that
see it swim along - literally if you dunk it in the bath, thanks to
waterproofing and floatability.

This bass-booming cylinder sounds great (with even better bass than before),
looks great, and is tough enough to tackle music in the office, for that
summer picnic or festival, or whatever else you happen to throw at it. It's
Bluetooth speaker bliss.

  * [Ultimate Ears UE Megaboom 3 review](/speakers/reviews/ultimate-ears/145462-ultimate-ears-ue-megaboom-3-review-speaker-portable-bluetooth)
  * [Which UE speaker is right for you?](/speakers/buyers-guides/ultimate-ears/145633-which-ue-speaker-is-best-megablast-blast-megaboom-boom-and-wonderboom-compared)

Pocket-lint

## Marshall Stockwell II

squirrel_widget_148684

It's not a party speaker - we'll leave that to the bigger [Kilburn II
(featured below)](/speakers/reviews/145667-marshall-kilburn-2-review-ii-
speaker) and larger-than-life Tufton - but this is a super-portable unit that
provides you with powerful audio on the go.

It's ideal for camping and picnics (both tried and tested by us). It probably
isn't going to be your main speaker at home - though it's totally capable of
being that if you so require.

As well as the standard Marshall bass, treble and volume controls, there's
also a battery level indicator too. You'll get well over 20 hours of listening
time out of it. Indeed, you'll try hard to remember the last time you had to
charge it.

  * [Marshall Stockwell II review](/speakers/reviews/147953-marshall-stockwell-ii-review)

Pocket-lint

## Sonos Move

squirrel_widget_167282

The Sonos Move is both a Bluetooth speaker and a Wi-Fi speaker - offering a
toggle on the rear to switch between the two modes. In Wi-Fi mode, it connects
to other Sonos speakers for a multi-room audio experience, while in Bluetooth
mode, it delivers a fantastic sound experience with plenty of bass and a
durable and water-resistant design. It will also automatically tune itself to
its surroundings.

It's not cheap by any stretch of the imagination and it's weighty too, which
means while it is portable - there's an integrated handle on the back - it's
not the kind of device you can pop in your backpack for a picnic. That said,
if you take it to the park or the beach, its sound and volume will impress (or
distress) most around you.

It's a great option for those with a Sonos system, offering the best of both
worlds - an excellent Wi-Fi smart speaker with AirPlay 2 support that you can
move around as you please.

  * [Sonos Move review](/speakers/reviews/sonos/149201-sonos-move-review-portable-bluetooth-speaker)

Pocket-lint

## B&O BeoPlay A1

squirrel_widget_138348

With a slightly different name to the more recent 2nd Gen "Beosound A2" (which
replaces this device), the BeoPlay A1 is a savvy option if you can find it for
a bargain price. Like the A2 its big sound makes it stand out.

Sure, there's no Wi-Fi, [AirPlay](/speakers/news/apple/141261-apple-
airplay-2-what-is-it-how-does-it-work-and-what-devices-are-supported),
waterproofing or 360-degree design like some of its competitors, but the solid
battery, build quality, extra bass punch and sheer audio clarity give this
speaker the upper hand when it comes to sound quality. It's well worth saving
up to buy.

  * [B&O BeoPlay A1 by Bang & Olufsen review](/speakers/reviews/bang-and-olufsen/138348-b-o-beoplay-a1-by-bang-and-olufsen-review-bluetooth-speaker-bliss)

Pocket-lint

## Ultimate Ears Boom 3

squirrel_widget_148748

The [UE Boom 2](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B014M909NC/?tag=pocketlintc07-20)
was excellent - it took taking one of our favourite portable Bluetooth
speakers, the original UE Boom, and made it even better - but the Boom 3 takes
this up a notch, while delivering a lower asking price.

If you're looking for portable, premium sound wherever you are, then the UE
Boom 3 hits the nail on the head. Have reasonable expectations for bass
delivery and it's one seriously hot Bluetooth speaker. If you want even more
then the Megaboom 3 (featured up page) is a beefed up version.

  * [Ultimate Ears UE Boom 3 review](/speakers/reviews/ultimate-ears/145473-ultimate-ears-ue-boom-3-review)

Pocket-lint

## Marshall Kilburn II

squirrel_widget_145667

The beauty of the powerful Kilburn II is its simplicity and portability. The
Kilburn II is truly a wall of sound; a bass blaster that turns it up to 10
(not 11, sorry). Mind you, if you get up to anything like that volume level
you'll be doing well to still be next to it.

We have listened to cleaner-sounding models and if you need 360-degree sound
then plump for the UE Megaboom 3 instead. Battery life is impressive at around
20 hours though and naturally, being a Marshall product, the whole speaker has
a very distinctive look and feel.

  * [Marshall Kilburn II review](/speakers/reviews/145667-marshall-kilburn-2-review-ii-speaker)

Pocket-lint

## Ultimate Ears Wonderboom 2

squirrel_widget_148842

If you want to invest in UE's range of portable Bluetooth speakers, but want
something smaller than the Boom or Megaboom, the Wonderboom is the one for
you.

When you turn it on, prepare yourself for an explosion of 360-degree sound
that belies its size. It's palm-sized, and like other speakers in the range,
is protected against knocks, bumps, drops and splashes thanks to its
rubberised casing and IP67 rating.

It can float too, so you can comfortably take it in the pool with you. What's
more, several colours are available - black, grey, red, blue and pink. It can
tackle all genres of music with aplomb and will add life to any social
scenario. You can even stereo pair two together.

  * [Ultimate Ears UE Wonderboom 2 review](/speakers/reviews/ultimate-ears/148230-ultimate-ears-wonderboom-2-review)

Pocket-lint

## BeoPlay P6

squirrel_widget_145767

Delivering sensational sound, there's lots to like about the P6 including its
beautiful sound quality and pleasant-to-use physical controls. It's also dust
and splash-proof and has a rechargeable battery that lasts a thoroughly decent
16 hours.

The only real disadvantage is the high asking price (which has come down a
bit) and you may want to look at the cheaper A1, above. There's also no 3.5mm
auxiliary input, either, which is a little disappointing.

  * [BeoPlay P6 review](/speakers/reviews/bang-and-olufsen/145767-beoplay-p6-review-speaker-bluetooth)

Pocket-lint

## JBL Xtreme 2

squirrel_widget_145677

This larger-scale portable speaker delivers loud and crisp sound, and even
though it doesn't have 360-degree sound it'll give you some pretty impressive
bass from the dual woofers.

It's undoubtedly a party speaker and also features a large carry handle plus
it's IPX7 water-resistant as well. There are only two disadvantages - a
reasonably hefty price point for one, along with physical heft owed to the
scale.

  * [JBL Xtreme 2 review](/speakers/reviews/jbl/145677-jbl-xtreme-2-review-portable-bluetooth-speaker)

Pocket-lint

## Denon Envaya DSB-250

squirrel_widget_143188

Denon is a well-known name from the world of Hi-Fi. And true to these roots,
Envaya is a great-sounding speaker that balances fidelity and power. In fact,
we'd go as far as to say it's one of the best-sounding small wireless speakers
around.

By the way, Denon has three models available, the 250BT being the largest and
naturally the beefiest. The Envaya Mini (150BT) and Envaya Pocket (50BT) slot
in underneath. The DSB-250 is semi-rugged, with [IP67 water
resistance](/phones/news/138727-ip-ratings-what-do-they-actually-mean). It can
handle being submerged in water a metre deep for half an hour.

  * [Denon Envaya DSB-250 review](/speakers/reviews/denon/143188-denon-envaya-dsb-250-review-sensational-sound-from-this-small-scale-portable-bluetooth-speaker)
